newsitem.title: USA: Rating upgrade from S&P not in cards for Illinois.
newsitem.headline: Rating upgrade from S&P not in cards for Illinois.

text.p: It wasn't the upgrade state of Illinois officials wanted, but Standard & Poor's Corp on Wednesday did improve the state's rating outlook to positive from stable.

Illinois' AA-minus general obligation rating was affirmed by Standard & Poor's for more than $5 billion of outstanding debt, as well as for a $185 million GO bond issue the state has scheduled for a competitive sale Sept. 4.
"We thought it was appropriate to recognize the state's strong budget progess," said Joe O'Keefe, a director at Standard & Poor's.

However, he pointed out that Illinois' rating was not upgraded because the state still faces a number of critical challenges over the next few years. Those include pension funding, education funding reform and implementation of a managed-care program for Medicaid recipients.
Mike Colsch, Illinois' deputy budget director, said he was "slightly disappointed" that the rating upgrade the state had sought did not materialize.
Still, he said he was pleased that Standard & Poor's recognized the financial progess the state has made by improving the rating outlook.
As for the critical challenges ahead cited by Standard & Poor's, Colsch said that the state has a mechanism in place to address funding of state pension funds.

But that funding system is currently being contested in a lawsuit brought by the state's five pension funds and their beneficiaries. If successful, the 1991 lawsuit could force the state to appropriate $2 billion to $3 billion for the pension funds, according to lawyers representing the plaintiffs.

Colsh said education funding reform is "clearly on the agenda" for the administration of Gov. Jim Edgar. Earlier this year, state lawmakers rejected Edgar's plan to place a proposed constitutional amendment on the ballot that would have required the state to fund a greater share of education.

In the area of Medicaid, Colsh said the state believes its MediPlan Plus managed-care system, which received federal approval last month, will result in improved monitoring, cost controls and services.
Illinois plans to place more than 1.1 million of Medicaid recipient into the system sometime next fiscal year.
Illinois is also awaiting ratings for its upcoming $185 million GO bond issue from Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Investors Service.
The Fitch rating will be the state's first since that rating agency was recapitalized and reactivated in 1989.
Colsh said contacts with market participants led the state to seek a third rating. He pointed out that most states now have a Fitch rating and that Fitch "has a strong municipal rating team."
